questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

 

  • Clarithromycin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 system, which is involved in the metabolism of many drugs, including digoxin. By inhibiting the metabolism of digoxin, clarithromycin can lead to elevated levels of digoxin in the blood, increasing the risk for digoxin toxicity.
  • Clarithromycin also acts as an inhibitor of the P-glycoprotein and can precipitate Digoxin toxicity. P glycoproteins are drug efflux pumps in the intestine that lead to a decrease in the bioavailability of drugs. Digoxin is one of the drugs that utilizes this mechanism for its metabolism. Therefore, the drugs which inhibit the Pgp can lead to the increased plasma concentration of Digoxin and lead to its toxicity.
  • Other drugs that inhibit the Pgp include 
    • Amiodarone
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Itraconazole
    • Propafenone
    • Flecainide 
    • Quinidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium chloride: This medication primarily affects potassium levels and has no significant interaction with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is not known to significantly interact with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option D. Triamterene: This diuretic medication primarily affects sodium and potassium levels and is not known to have a significant impact on digoxin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: National Deworming Day is observed on:(FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10 February and 10 August

 

National Deworming Day is observed on 10th February, with a repeat round conducted after six months on 10th August. During this program, albendazole is used for deworming. In many states, the 10th date of every month is observed as national deworming day, but the main nationwide observance is on these two dates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

National Deworming Day is observed on 10th February with a repeat round after 6 months on 10th August, using albendazole for deworming.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. She is prescribed metronidazole as part of her treatment plan. Which of the following should she avoid consuming while on this medication? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol

 

  • Patients taking metronidazole are advised to avoid alcohol consumption. Metronidazole and alcohol can interact to cause a disulfiram-like reaction, leading to symptoms such as flushing, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and even more severe reactions in some cases. This interaction can occur not only with oral alcohol consumption but also with alcohol contained in mouthwashes and certain medications.
  • Disulfiram is an aversive drug, that inhibits the aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body, which can lead to symptoms like throbbing headache, flushing, chest tightness, visual disturbances, nausea etc. Hence these symptoms prevent the patient from taking alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grapefruit juice: There is no known significant interaction between grapefruit juice and metronidazole.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepine: While caution may be advised when combining any medications that can have CNS effects, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between benzodiazepines and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Option D. SSRI: Similar to benzodiazepines, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between SSRIs and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs that can cause disulfiram like reaction include:

 

Cyclic:  Cefoperazone, Chlorpropamide

 

G:         Grieseofulvin

 

M:        Metronidazole

 

P:         Procarbazine

questions.text: During a surgical procedure in the ear, the surgeon injured a nerve which led to lagophthalmos after the surgery. Which nerve was likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cranial nerve 7

 

Lagophthalmos is the inability to fully close the eyelids, typically due to paralysis of the orbicularis oculi muscle. This muscle is innervated by the facial nerve, also known as Cranial Nerve 7. During ear surgery, the facial nerve can be vulnerable to injury, especially in procedures involving the middle ear or mastoid region. Damage to this nerve results in a loss of motor control to the muscles of facial expression, including those responsible for eyelid closure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial nerve 8: It is vestibulo cochlear nerve which is having the function of hearing & equilibrium

 

Option C. Cranial nerve 6: The sixth cranial nerve, or abducens nerve, controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for eye abduction. Injury to this nerve causes problems with lateral eye movement, not with eyelid closure, making it an incorrect choice.

 

Option D. Cranial nerve 5: The fifth cranial nerve, or trigeminal nerve, is primarily responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing. While it has a minor role in reflexive blinking (via the corneal reflex), it does not control the orbicularis oculi muscle, so its injury would not cause lagophthalmos.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial nerve (Cranial Nerve 7) controls the muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi muscle, and injury to this nerve can result in lagophthalmos.
